thread.title: Shark tooth hunt for kids comes to Tybee Island
thread.title_full: Shark tooth hunt for kids comes to Tybee Island

author: Heather Henley
title: Shark tooth hunt for kids comes to Tybee Island
text:
Tweet 
Brian Stafford admits he doesn’t have children of his own so he’s not as confident with trying to make the youngsters happy, but he’s doing everything he can to make sure his first Kids Shark Tooth/Fossil Hunt “is perfect.” 
After years of planning and organizing popular charity bar crawls, Stafford is taking on his first family-friendly charity event with the Tybee Island event from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Oct. 18. 
The event is for children ages 2-12 (with an accompanying adult). Children are divided into groups by age — 2-6 and 7-12 — and tickets are $20 in advance or $25 the day of the event. 
IF YOU GO 
What: Tybee Island Kids Shark Tooth/Fossil Hunt 
When: 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Oct. 18 
Where: Tybee Island, North Beach 
Cost: $20 advance; $25 day of event 
Info: www.StaffordPromotions.com/SavannahEvents 
Accompanying adults are admitted free. The event benefits Tybee Island Marine Science Center and tickets can be purchased online. 
Stafford says he’s had the idea for a shark tooth hunt on Tybee for a while and through his research, he stumbled upon Mike Harris, aka the Shark Tooth Fairy and Capt. Morgan , out of Beaufort, S.C. 
Stafford says Harris puts on these types of events and is also a diver who finds the shark teeth, including the prehistoric Megalodon teeth that are as big as 7 inches long. 
Harris will be at the Tybee event to help identify teeth as they are found and he is also donating several large Megalodon teeth for children to discover and take home. 
At the hunt, children will also be able to find prehistoric mako, bull, sand, great white and snaggletooth shark teeth/fossils. 
Stafford says shark tooth hunters can come out as early at 10 a.m. to begin searching for teeth and stay as long as they want, but he asks that children only keep 20 teeth each so there are enough to go around. If you find 20 teeth but want to keep looking, that’s OK. 
Stafford says to just put back smaller teeth and keep searching for bigger teeth. 
Stafford and his staff will begin hiding teeth at 9 a.m. and his stash includes 25 Megalodon teeth and about 15,000 smaller teeth. 
The event features other educational activities and food from Toppin’ Hotdogs Café. 
“This is just the first one,” he adds. I want to eventually do two a year, one in the fall and one in spring ... I want these events to be huge with live music and more vendors. I want to make it so big so that everyone knows ... what day the annual Shark Tooth Hunt is.” 
While Stafford expects the weather to be beautiful, he does want people to remember that parking on North Beach is limited and everyone should plan ahead. 
Shuttles and taxis are available all over the island and Stafford has a list of shuttle providers and phone numbers, as well as a list of rules/regulations, on his Facebook event page for the hunt.
